title: Rain From Tropical Storm Inundates Parts of Texas
text:
Police evacuate people from their neighborhood, which was inundated by rain, on Thursday in Splendora, Texas.

HOUSTON—Flooding hit Southeast Texas, shutting down some roads and the airport in Houston and forcing rescuers to evacuate people around Beaumont, 80 miles to the east.

As of 11:30 a.m. local time Thursday, 26 inches of rain had fallen in 12 hours in Hamshire, Texas, just south of Beaumont. Some areas had seen as much as 42 inches since Tropical Depression Imelda began approaching the area near the Louisiana border Tuesday afternoon, according to local government data.

The Beaumont Police Department said Thursday morning it was fielding more than 270 requests for evacuations. The Texas Game Wardens reported they were conducting a “major response” in the Beaumont area.

The Texas Department of Transportation reported that flooding left various roadways inaccessible, including Interstate 10 south of Beaumont. Authorities urged people to avoid driving, if possible. Gov. Greg Abbott declared a state of disaster in 13 Texas counties affected by the storm. A man walking into high water near Patton Village, Texas. Photo: Brett Coomer/Houston Chronicle/Associated Press On social media, residents and visitors in Beaumont reported being trapped in homes, stores and hotels. The Cajun Navy, a volunteer rescue organization, urged people with boats to report for rescues in the area. The Jefferson County Sheriff’s Office ordered evacuations of Gilbert Lake Estates, a subdivision located south of Beaumont. The department wrote on Facebook Thursday morning that a levee holding up to 5,600 acres of water “could break at any moment.” In Houston, flooding became worse throughout the day Thursday. Jeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, warned on Twitter of potential life-threatening flash flooding throughout the metro area. Mr. Lindner said rainfall rates Thursday morning were averaging 5 inches to 6.5 inches per hour in eastern Houston. As the storm moved south, roadways around the city began to flood and close. The Houston-Bush Intercontinental Airport reported that it was at a full ground stop as of 9:30 a.m. local time. In an 11 a.m. update, the airport said its terminals and concessions remained open, but streets surrounding the airport were flooded. An FAA update said the airport was expected to remain closed until Friday afternoon. All city bus and train service was halted. City officials said in an afternoon news conference that the situation in Houston was improving, but still urged caution. By 3 p.m., the rate of rainfall had slowed to about half an inch per hour, Mayor Sylvester Turner said. The Harris County Sheriff’s Office reported it had fielded calls for 133 high water rescues in the Houston area before noon. Most of the emergency phone calls in Houston were for stranded drivers, officials said. “Everyone is going to have to exercise a high degree of patience,” Mr. Turner said. “Even though it may not be raining as much, it doesn’t mean the water is going to quickly subside” Corrections & Amplifications

An earlier version of this article incorrectly spelled Hamshire, Texas as Hampshire. Sept. 19.
